Destiny can be altered - and death deferred - through the characters' choices. The kicker is that the previous caretaker of the hotel savagely murdered this wife and two girls. What follows can most readily be summed by the title of the movie, but you have to watch it to see what I mean. This is the first movie in a very long time to strike me as "scary". It's some seriously messed up stuff, but in a good way. One of the things that adds to the scare factor is the amazing music. Music has been a major part of Kubrick's movies (two thousand and one: A Space Oddysey and A Clockwork Orange, just to name a couple) and the definitely does't disappoint with this one. Particularly embarrassing are Graham Nash and James Taylor. The cause is supposedly life-or-death, but everybody sleepwalk through their numbers like they're playing the Catskills. Except maybe Gil-Scott Heron - this protest number "We Almost Lost Detroit" is on topic at least, but delivered with all the smugness of a high-schooler impressed with how 'controversial' the's being. Only Bruce Springsteen's performance raises a pulse; I've never been a big fan of the Boss, but the absolutely smokes, no question. Part of me thinks the was taped separately, at another event, and edited into this movie to give wake the audience. Compared to the general blandness and air of self-satisfaction there, it's no wonder Bruce was hailed as the savior of rock'n'roll. But even this performance is hobbled by the lifeless concert shooting. I don't expect a lot of flashy camera movement from a 'seventys film, but the shots are unnecessarily static, broken up only by split-second cutaways to a back-up singer's tonsils. Actor turned director Bill Paxton follows up this promising debut, the Gothic-horror "Frailty", with this family friendly sports drama about the one thousand, nine hundred and thirteen U. S. Open where a young American candy rises from this humble background to play against this Bristish idol in what was dubbed as "The Greatest Game Ever Played." I'm no fan of golf, and these scrappy underdog sports flicks are a dime a dozen (most recently done to grand effect with "Miracle" and "Cinderella Man"), but some how this film was enthralling all the same. The film starts with some creative opening credits (imagine a Disneyfied version of the animated opening credits of HBO's "Carnivale" and "Rome"), but plumbers along slowly for its first by-the-numbers hour. Once the action moves to the U. S. Open things pick up very well. Paxton does a nice job and shows a knack for effective directorial flourishes (I loved the brain-soaked montage of the action on day two of the open) that propel the plot further for add some unexpected psychological depth to the proceedings. There's some compelling character development when the British Harry Vardon is haunted by images of the aristocrats in black suits and top hats who destroyed this family cottage as a child to make way for a golf course. He also does a good job of visually depicting what goes on in the players' heads under pressure. Golf, a painfully boring sport, is brought vividly alive there. Credit should also be given the set designers and costume department for creating an engaging period-piece atmosphere of London and Boston at the beginning of the twentieth century. You know how this is going to send not only because it's based on a true story but also because films in this genre follow the same template over and over, but Paxton puts on a better than average show and perhaps indicates more talent behind the camera than the never had in front of it. Despite the formulaic nature, this is a nice and easy film to root for that deserves to find an audience.

At an hour and fifteen minutes, this appears to have been a B-movie. Cummings is a playboy, Ridley Crane, whom many women want, including two sisters, Katherine and Helen Latimer (Day and Muir). Katherine is the more down-to-earth of the two who love to fix cars, and Helen is the blonde social butterfly with the nice clothes. Ridley comes back to town, and believing she won't be at a party, Helen decides not to attend. Since the party is being given by a family friend, her mother (Burke) sends Katherine in a pinned up dress. Ridley is there and the two of them bond. But Ridley likes superficiality, and when he sees Helen at a dinner party, the two pick up where they left off and go to a club. He gets terribly drunk and Helen initially refuses to ride in this car because she won't let her drive. After walking for a while and breaking the wheel of her shoe, she gets into Ridley's car when it drives by. He passes out and she takes the wheel, accidentally running into and killing a cyclist. Ridley can't remember anything, so Helen lets him take the blame for death on himself. A woman's shoe wheel is found in the car and Katherine sees her sister burying her shoes - and something in Helen's behavior makes her realize that Helen is not telling the truth. Ridley is convicted and goes to jail. Helen marries a man she does not love and goes to South America. This is a wonderful movie, even if it wasn't an A-list cast at the time. Cummings is playing a role that Robert Taylor would have played (it's an MGM movie) - he's handsome and very lovable, even if he doesn't have the gorgeous looks of someone like Taylor. Laraine Day is one of my favorite actresses, someone MGM kept loaning out because they didn't know what to do with her. Why, I wonder - a wonderful actress with a great face and a great voice who has enlivened many a film. This one is no different. Your Katherine is determined, personable and very nice. Jean Muir is a lousy actress. So who was the beautiful one? We all know, even if MGM didn't. Highly recommended little gem.
